title: Fisherman set for better life after finding £250,000 worth of whale vomit

A fisherman has struck it lucky - after stumbling upon a huge lump of whale vomit.

Jumrus Thiachot spotted the 14lb piece while he was walking along the beach in Koh Samui, Thailand, earlier this year.

The 55-year-old, who earns around 400 baht (£10.25) a day, asked neighbours to conduct some tests to check the substance but was told that the results failed to prove.

He had been keeping the vomit for a year before he contacted the government authorities for an inspection.

Officials visited him at his home on Tuesday where they confirmed the waxy lump was genuine whale vomit, also known as Ambergrisis.

(Image: ViralPress)

He said: "Three of my neighbours came after my nephew told the villagers that I found a whale vomit.

"They asked for slices and said they will run some checks to prove that it was really a whale vomit, but they said the tests didn't show anything.

"I needed to know the truth, so that's why I contacted the authorities to check. Now I know it is real whale vomit I will sell it."

The 14lbs whale vomit mass is estimated to worth as much as $320,000 (£247,603), based on previous sale prices.

(Image: ViralPress)

Surat Thani provincial governor Witchawuth Jinto arrived with specialists and they confirmed that the chunk contained more than 80 percent of Ambergris.

Witchawuth said they are now advising Jumrus on what he should do next to get the best price for his lucky find.

Ambergris is produced by sperm whales when their bile ducts in the gastrointestinal tract make secretions to ease the passage of large or sharp objects.

The whale them vomits the mucilage which solidifies and has a foul smell.

(Image: ViralPress)

However, after it dries out the chunk will smell more pleasant, which makes it a sought-after ingredient in the perfume fragrance industry, because of its good long-lasting smell.

In April 2016, a 1.57 kilogram ambergris ball found in Lancashire sold for £50,000 while in November of the same year, three Omani fishermen found 80kg of ambergris and sold it for $3 million.
